dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 5301 IH: Eliminate Useless Reports Act of 2023
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Robert Garcia of California (for himself and Mr. Grothman) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Accountability, and in addition to the Committee on the Budget, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend title 31, United States Code, to require agencies to include a list of outdated or duplicative reporting requirements in annual budget justifications, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Eliminate Useless Reports Act of 2023.

subsection.text: Section 1125 of title 31, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking subsections (a) and (b) and inserting the following:
The term budget justification materials has the meaning given the term in section 3(b)(2) of the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006 (31 U.S.C. 6101 note; Public Law 109–282).
The term recurring plan or report—

subparagraph.text: means any plan or report submitted to Congress by not less than 1 agency on a recurring basis—

clause.text: in accordance with Federal law; or
at the direction of a congressional report; and

subparagraph.text: does not include any plan or report that is required to be submitted to the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate.

paragraph.text: The term relevant congressional committee means a congressional committee to which a recurring plan or report is required to be submitted.
The head of each agency shall include in the budget justification materials of the agency—

subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2), a list of each recurring plan or report submitted by the agency that the head of the agency determines to be outdated or duplicative;
with respect to each recurring plan or report described in subparagraph (A)—

clause.text: a recommendation on whether to sunset, modify, consolidate, or reduce the frequency of the submission of the recurring plan or report;
a citation to each provision of law or directive in a congressional report that requires or requests the submission of the recurring plan or report; and
a list of the relevant congressional committees for the recurring plan or report; and

subparagraph.text: a justification explaining, with respect to each recommendation described in subparagraph (B)(i) relating to a recurring plan or report—

clause.text: why the head of the agency made the recommendation, which may include an estimate of the resources expended by the agency to prepare and submit the recurring plan or report; and
the understanding of the head of the agency of the purpose of the recurring plan or report.

subparagraph.text: In preparing the list required under paragraph (1)(A), if, in submitting a recurring plan or report, an agency is required to coordinate or consult with another agency or entity, the head of the agency submitting the recurring plan or report shall consult with the head of each agency or entity with whom consultation or coordination is required.

If, after a consultation under subparagraph (A), the head of each agency or entity consulted under that subparagraph agrees that a recurring plan or report is outdated or duplicative, the head of the agency required to submit the recurring plan or report shall—

clause.text: include the recurring plan or report in the list described in paragraph (1)(A); and
identify each agency or entity with which the head of the agency is required to coordinate or consult in submitting the recurring plan or report.

subparagraph.text: If the head of any agency or entity consulted under subparagraph (A) does not agree that a recurring plan or report is outdated or duplicative, the head of the agency required to submit the recurring plan or report shall not include the recurring plan or report in the list described in paragraph (1)(A).

paragraph.header: Government-wide or multi-agency plan and report submissions
paragraph.text: With respect to a recurring plan or report required to be submitted by not less than 2 agencies, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall—

subparagraph.text: determine whether the requirement to submit the recurring plan or report is outdated or duplicative; and

paragraph.text: With respect to a recommendation on a recurring plan or report included in budget justification materials by the head of an agency under subsection (b)(1)(B)(i), the chair and ranking member of each relevant congressional committee may—

subparagraph.text: in coordination with any other relevant congressional committee, as necessary, agree or disagree with the recommendation or postpone a decision on the recommendation; and
notify each agency that submits a recommendation of the disposition of the recommendation under subparagraph (A).

paragraph.text: If a relevant congressional committee agrees with an agency recommendation submitted under subsection (b)(1)(B)(i), the relevant congressional committee may take the necessary legislative steps to accomplish the recommendation, which may include consulting with the agency that submits the recurring plan or report that is the subject of the recommendation to prepare appropriate legislation.
Nothing in this section shall be construed to relieve the head of an agency from a requirement to submit a recurring plan or report.

in subsection (d), as so redesignated, by striking in the budget of the United States Government, as provided by section 1105(a)(37) and inserting in the budget justification materials of each agency.

subsection.text: Section 1105(a) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by striking paragraph (39).
